Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing the Molecular Gas Contents of High Redshift Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astrophysicists are just beginning to unravel the details of the early Universe and the history of star formation. Because molecular gas is the fuel for star formation, it is crucial to understand its characteristics when most stars formed, a time when the Universe was about 15% of its current age. The aim of this project is to test the theoretical picture of galaxy formation that makes the robust prediction that very distant star forming galaxies have large gas reservoirs. The principal investigator (PI) will perform a thorough characterization of molecular gas in very distant (high redshift) galaxies. This project involves a multi-year observing program conducted at newly commissioned radio and millimeter interferometers.

These observations will be used to measure the ground state emission from carbon monoxide (CO) in seven star forming galaxies in one of the most distant known galaxy clusters. With these data the PI will derive the gas mass, gas consumption timescales, star formation efficiencies, dynamical masses, and gas fractions, and will increase the total available sample with such robust measurements by a factor of three. The PI will perform a similar analysis of about 30 galaxies by targeting a set of newly discovered high redshift over-densities. This sample size will enable a unique study of the gas contents and the physical conditions of the gas as a function of redshift and stellar mass. This analysis will be the first examination of how the molecular gas contents of high redshift galaxies depend on their environment.

Educationally, the PI will design and implement an outreach program at Lawrence High School. The goals of this program are to teach research techniques, the nature of science, and the electromagnetic spectrum. Students in this program will use data from the Spitzer Space Telescope to measure the star formation rates of cluster galaxies. The program will involve 20 students and span over two years. The best two students will present their findings at an American Astronomical Society meeting. The program will be jointly run by a physics teacher at the school, a graduate student, and the PI. By providing opportunities for continuing education to the high school teacher and by providing the teacher with research tools and data, this program will become self-sustaining. The effectiveness of the activities will be rigorously and quantitatively assessed. The PI will additionally perform research with undergraduates, who will present their findings at an American Astronomical Society meeting. The PI will also organize an annual meeting of extragalactic astronomers and their students at institutes close to the PI's institution in order to provide opportunities for the students to exchange ideas and present their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  This project studied the properties of galaxies in a galaxy cluster that lies 9.5 billion light years away from our own galaxy.  The main goal of the project was to study how star formation in these galaxies is regulated by their supply of gas, which is the fuel for star formation.  This gas, in the form of molecular hydrogen, is not easily detectable.  The PI therefore used emission from another gas, Carbon Monoxide (CO) as a tracer of molecular Hydrogen.  The PI used data from one of the world’s largest radio telescopes, the Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA) to measure the amount of CO in these galaxies and thereby infer their amount of molecular hydrogen.  The PI then combined these gas mass measurements with measures of the mass in stars for each galaxy, the rate at which new stars are being formed, and the history of how stars formed.   With this information the PI was able to achieve the following outcomes:

The PI determined that the cluster still had to stop star formation in many of its galaxies, in order to have the right amount of galaxies with no star formation that are seen in more nearby clusters.  This cessation of star formation had to be accompanied by a significant amount of merging between the galaxies, so that the number of galaxies of different brightnesses matched observations.  

The PI measured the gas content of the distant cluster galaxies and found that they had significant fuel for ongoing star formation but that this fuel supply needed to be truncated in order for the galaxies to turn into their likely descendant galaxies in more nearby (and hence more recent) clusters.  

The skills that the PI obtained working on this project were also brought to bear on a variety of other published scientific projects such as understanding how galaxies with massive amounts of star formation are able to expel their own fuel and thus shut down their continued formation.  

The project has significantly expanded the scientific reach of the PI and given astronomers important new elements in their understanding of galaxy formation in dense regions of the early universe.

 

Broader Impact: This project conceived of and successfully implemented an outreach program in a local high school.  The PI worked with a local high school teacher and an employee of this grant to create a year-long course in the high school.  The first semester of this course consisted of essentially a college-level introductory astronomy class.  The second semester of this course consisted of a research project performed using data from the Spitzer Space Telescope.  In this project, the students used the Spitzer data to measure the rate at which stars were forming in galaxies that were in the process of falling into galaxy clusters that lie approximately 6 billion light years from earth.  They combined these data with those from major ground-based observatories to determine which galaxies in their images belonged to the cluster.  They measured that the fraction of galaxies that is forming stars drops towards the centers of the galaxy clusters.  

During this project the students were taught skills in critical thinking, quantitative analysis of complex data, communication of these data and of their scientific results, assessment of the the reliability of their results, and how to deal with open-ended ambiguous problems.  The capstone element of the project was a poster presentation at a mini-symposium at the University of Kansas.  

30 students have gone through the program during the lifetime of this project.  This total was comprised of ~50% underrepresented student groups: four African American, three Hispanic, one Native American, and 10 female students, two of which were also women of color. 

This program has been hailed as a resounding success by the administrators in the school system, by our host high school teacher, and by the participants.  Nearly all of the students are attending college and many are going into STEM fields.  They all indicate that this course improved their appreciation of science.
